_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Facility Description and Regulated Substances                                                                                                      Trams Industrial, LLC, (the Owner) purchased the subject real estate and improvements from a closed business entity, Commercial Distribution Center, Inc., on April 1, 2012, and leased the property to Smart Warehousing, LLC, (the Operator).  Smart Warehousing is engaged in the same general business as the former site operator, i.e., managing a controlled climate warehouse and distribution services company with a variety of storage areas including dry storage, chilled storage (down to -5 deg. F) and humidity-controlled environments to ensure or prolong product integrity.  The facility is located in Independence, Missouri, within an underground structure that resulted from the mining of limestone. Smart Warehousing benefits from an ambient temperature of 58 degrees F. in the underground structure, making it more efficient (than surface storage) to achieve freezer and other refrigeration temperatures. The facility has rail line connectivity and truck docks.  The refrigeration and freezer warehouses at the facility are cooled with brine, which is chilled by an anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system.  The anhydrous ammonia is stored above grade and piped to a below grade mechanical room where it is used to super cool a brine solution.  The brine is then piped to specified areas to refrigerate those areas.   Anhydrous ammonia is the only substance present at the facility in quantites exceeding the U.S. EPA's Risk Management Plan thresholds.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies                                                                                          Smart Warehousing has a mechanical integrity program based on industry standards for equipment inspections and preventive maintenance practices, including practices and procedures recommended by the International Institute of Ammonia Refrige

ration (IIAR).  Our emergency response policy with regard to potential substantial releases of anhydrous ammonia stipulates evacuation of personnel from the underground complex (if necessary) and notification of the primary emergency response agency (the Independence Fire Department) and a pre-identified local area contract emergency response firm, HAZMAT Response, Inc (Olathe, Kansas).         



Accidental Release Prevention Program           

The ammonia refrigeration equipment is generally inspected each work-week day (Monday-Friday; but at a minimum of every 72 hours) by a qualified operator.  Smart Warehousing has a preventive maintenance system that emphas replacement of parts and equipment at recommended frequencies or at any sign of undue wear or impending failure.  The control system is equipped with automatic shut down features that are designed to prevent accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the event of significant upset conditions or equipment malfunction.  The facility has a 24-hour manned security presence, as well as remote video monitoring of equipment with a large ammonia inventory.         



Five-Year Accident History      

Smart Warehousing initiated operation of the storage facility on April 1, 2012.  As of July, 2012, there have been no accidents associated with the Smart Warehousing ammonia refrigeration system which meet the RMP requirements for listing in the facility accident history.  To the best of our knowledge, there was not an RMP defined accident in the 5 years prior to Trams Industries' acquisition of the facility.   



Emergency Response Program

Smart Warehousing facility employees are not qualified to respond to an uncontrolled or large quantity release of ammonia refrigerant.  Due to the toxic nature of ammonia, employees will generally not respond to any release other than minor releases that do not pose an undue safety hazard (e.g., tightening a valve gasket packing).  The facility has no Spill Response Team.  Fac

ility personnel are trained to notify the Independence Fire Department and a contract emergency response firm in the event of a significant release of ammonia, and to provide technical support to responders as requested.  Prior to Smart Warehousing's operation of the facility, the previous operator notified the Mid-America Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and the Independence Fire Department (IFD) of the presence and quantity of liquid anhydrous ammonia on the site and provided the results of the Worst Case Scenario analysis to the LEPC and IFD; and made a request to include the facility in the community emergency response plan developed by the LEPC.  



Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Smart Warehousing has authorized the performance of a Prevention Program Compliance Audit by a third party in order to identify potential improvements to process safety.  The Audit will be initiated in 2012 and process improvements, if identified, will be initiated in 2013.

Smart Warehousing will also notify the LEPC and the IFD of the change of site operating entity and the continuance of site operations with respect to storage and use of anhydrous ammonia.
